channel.title: Please Critique my First Website!
channel.description:
If you'd be so kind as to check out my first website, I'd greatly appreciate it. I wrote it from the ground up, using DreamWeaver only to write code. I learned SQL and PHP like last night, so I'm not entirely sure if the posting system is secure or not. Please try it out!
[b][u][url=http://www.codenameworld.com/index.php]My Website[/url][/u][/b]
Thanks,
~Lin

item.title: Please Critique my First Website!
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

That looks much better Lin. Great improvement!

Read full topic

item.title: Please Critique my First Website!
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:13, topic:550138”][quote author=Lin link=topic=669049.msg4474112#msg4474112 date=1424738010]

" Are you saying the thumbnail should be further from the text?" Yes, I’m saying that the thumbnail on the front pages should be further from the text, similar to how you have done it on the other pages.
[/quote]Oh, that’s not a thumbnail. It’s an actual post without a thumbnail that contains an image that happened to have text immediately after it. It uses the same picture and similar positioning though so I don’t blame you for getting confused.

It doesn’t matter if it is an image or a thumbnail, it needs padding. It looks ugly when the next is right next to the image.[/quote]That’s a good idea. I’ll take care of it.

Anyways, I’ve taken some design issues into consideration and fixed most of the bugs that were there. I have not added the character encoding yet, and there’s some other minor issues like no alt text on the image and a duplicate div id, but that’s all for some other time. Any further suggestions are welcome.

www.codenameworld.com

Read full topic

item.title: Please Critique my First Website!

item.description:

" Are you saying the thumbnail should be further from the text?" Yes, I’m saying that the thumbnail on the front pages should be further from the text, similar to how you have done it on the other pages.
[/quote]Oh, that’s not a thumbnail. It’s an actual post without a thumbnail that contains an image that happened to have text immediately after it. It uses the same picture and similar positioning though so I don’t blame you for getting confused.[/quote]
It doesn’t matter if it is an image or a thumbnail, it needs padding. It looks ugly when the next is right next to the image.

Read full topic

item.title: Please Critique my First Website!
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:10, topic:550138”]" Are you saying the thumbnail should be further from the text?" Yes, I’m saying that the thumbnail on the front pages should be further from the text, similar to how you have done it on the other pages.[/quote]Oh, that’s not a thumbnail. It’s an actual post without a thumbnail that contains an image that happened to have text immediately after it. It uses the same picture and similar positioning though so I don’t blame you for getting confused.

[quote=“vortex, post:11, topic:550138”]HTML is not case sensitive, you could WriTe YoUR Tags liKE ThIs if you wanted to but it’d look fudgeing retarded

also browse the palettes here and pick one or five http://www.colourlovers.com/[/quote]So then a browser that can’t properly read the doctype tag is just a bad browser. Nice palette site, I’ll check it out. Makes more sense than choosing colors and hoping they work.

Read full topic

item.title: Please Critique my First Website!
item.dc:creator: @stCky stCky
item.description:
@stCky wrote:

Dreamweaver, as great as it might seem it will at times insert it’s own bloat code (for legacy and cross browser support etc) and is generally a bit clunky, as Ruby mentioned you should be doing all your styling in a separate stylesheet and stay away from inline styles (<div style=“xxx”) as much as possible. You might find using a lighter editor such as Notepad++ or Sublime Text a bit easier once you have the basics of html/css down - I’ve never once opted for a full blown IDE for any php/mysql/javascript/html/css and we were recommended to move away from Dreamweaver as fast as possible where I studied.

It’s common for people to create a base list of common classes to avoid “quickly adding styles into html”, some examples below:

.left{float: left;}
.right{float: right;}
.clear{clear: both;}

.aligncenter{text-align: center;}
.alignleft{text-align: left;}
.alignright{text-align: right;}

.orange{text-color: orange;} /* easily set text to orange, a common colour for your design possibly */

Other than that and the mentioned broken tags - great work for your first site, you indicate clearly where the user is currently viewing the site and the sections all make sense.

I’m available all day on skype and happy to help with anything I can - PM me for my skype if you ever want to discuss web stuff.

Read full topic

item.title: Please Critique my First Website!
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:4, topic:550138”]You forgot to close one of your div tags

<h1>Embedded image test</h1><div style="padding:0 0 20px 0;"

But to me it looks like the posts stand out off the page too much, and they don’t really blend together with the other posts[/quote]Thanks for pointing that out.

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:5, topic:550138”]It needs more padding between the image and the next next to it, and the padding here needs to be consistent: http://www.codenameworld.com/updates.php[/quote]The first post is intentionally spaced further away from the other two, and all other posts are consistently close together. Are you saying the thumbnail should be further from the text?

[quote=“Ruby, post:6, topic:550138”]Few small things after just scanning the code, I’m a little rusty so there’s probably deeper issues but these are the obvious ones.

When you declare your doctype it’s all lowercase, it that should be . Most browsers read it either way but some obscure piece of ass browser might fudge it up.

You’re doing some styling in the CSS file (how it should be done) and some styling through HTML. ALL styling should be carried out using CSS with no exceptions.

You open a few tags that you don’t close, the one that Justin mentioned on line 29 is causing the error of not allowing the following tag to open because it’s recognised as an attribute of the previous div tag giving you an error on line 44 as the browser recognises the opening tag as non existent and therefore the closing tag useless. On line 12

is opened and never closed. On line 40, you double close your

tag, remove one of them.

Probably missed some stuff, but that should be enough to get it to validate.[/quote]HTML is case sensitive? And yes, I realize not putting everything in a CSS file is bad practice, but it’s just so much easier to quickly add some into the HTML… And thank you for the missing tags. Unfortunately with how I’m doing templating, I don’t get the luxury of syntax highlighting anywhere but the main template, so it’s not surprising I missed some stuff.

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:7, topic:550138”]http://validator.w3.org/check?uri=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.codenameworld.com%2Findex.php&charset=(detect+automatically)&doctype=Inline&group=0

https://jigsaw.w3.org/css-validator/validator?uri=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.codenameworld.com%2Findex.php&profile=css3&usermedium=all&warning=1&vextwarning=&lang=en

These sites are really good at explaining common formatting fudgeups[/quote]Oh wow, that is exceptionally useful. Thanks, I’ll definitely be using that a lot!

Thank you everyone for the feedback. The main complaint seems to be the way the posts look, so I’ll redesign them and ask for critique again.

Read full topic

These sites are really good at explaining common formatting fuckups

Read full topic

item.title: Please Critique my First Website!
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

Few small things after just scanning the code, I’m a little rusty so there’s probably deeper issues but these are the obvious ones.

When you declare your doctype it’s all lowercase, it that should be . Most browsers read it either way but some obscure piece of ass browser might fuck it up.

You’re doing some styling in the CSS file (how it should be done) and some styling through HTML. ALL styling should be carried out using CSS with no exceptions.

You open a few tags that you don’t close, the one that Justin mentioned on line 29 is causing the error of not allowing the following tag to open because it’s recognised as an attribute of the previous div tag giving you an error on line 44 as the browser recognises the opening tag as non existent and therefore the closing tag useless. On line 12

is opened and never closed. On line 40, you double close your

tag, remove one of them.

Probably missed some stuff, but that should be enough to get it to validate.

Read full topic

@HcoJustin wrote:

You forgot to close one of your div tags

<h1>Embedded image test</h1><div style="padding:0 0 20px 0;"

But to me it looks like the posts stand out off the page too much, and they don’t really blend together with the other posts

item.description:
@Lin wrote:

Thank you very much. Admittedly the posts do look kind of funky now that you mention it. Their style doesn’t fit with the rest of the website. I’ll look into giving them a cleaner, more modern look.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

A nice clean design - good work Lin! The only thing I’m not a fan of is the roundness of the posts. I think they’d look better if kept flat like the rest of the design.
